Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i think for crypto valuations, it would be similar to real estate. why would  a house that costs $20,000 to build be worth $2 mil? if the neighbor houses are all $2 mil and about the same type of house.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: there is no way there would be rents to justify the $2 mil valuation, so it isnt the cashflow

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: there are only so many coins, a finite supply. which is a very new concept for money, so when valuing crypto against something that will forever devalue (fiat), it is just a matter of time before the price of crypto goes up significantly

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: BTC is sort of the hardmoney standard of crypto, with miners spending $5000 to $8000 per coin. if BTC wasnt worth more than that, they wouldnt be doing this. now is BTC worth 10000x what KMD is? is it worth "only" 1000x or 100000x? in real estate you compare to comparables. currently KMD is far away from BTC, so you need to compare it to the others near #50, and each coin in the top 100 is being valued against its neighbors

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: should BTC be worth more than all the other coins combined? i would say that over time, this cant be sustained, but network effect will keep it there a lot longer than the tech would warrant

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: approximating to half, then the question is asked about each coin below and what percentage of overall marketcap makes sense, starting with the remaining half. it is only small fractions by the time you get to where KMD is now. using a comparables valuation, it seems KMD is headed higher in the rankings. especially now that china has discovered it

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: ultimately, the crypto valuation question is answered by whether BTC belongs at #35 on https://fiatmarketcap.com/

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: when it comes to valuing currencies, its all relative

Author: Mylo#8306
Content:
The chips/atomicdex flow for a game is an interesting point @jspook16 
James has said in the past that it is possible btc won‚Äôt be the king of crypto valuations.  Stablecoins likely.

Where are stablecoins going to be utilized?  In my opinion it is in multichain ecosystems.  The komodo‚Äôs cosmos‚Äôs polkadots verus.

Why in those ecosystems?  Because they will provide developers (and organizations) an arguable order of magnitude more sovereignty and security than eth v1.0 provided in 2016-2018 which.

If there are stablecoins in those ecosystems why bother with crypto like kmd atom or dots?  Because of bridges between services, dev costs, tech debt, new opportunities and functions not supported by stablecoin provider.  The devs of stablecoin have different goals to ecosystem providers and different weaknesses/pain points.

Edit:  verus chain ecosystem

Author: jspook16#3059
Content: Yeah I was thinking something similar I was unable to articulate it though. Great point

Author: Arno#3334
Content: Here's a question regarding the classification of the KMD currency, please correct me if my assumptions are wrong: Since there has been an ICO for the KMD coins and they have not been mined from zero supply like Bitcoin (thus pre-mined), isn't there the danger of the SEC coming after Komodo as they did with many other ICO projects, and classifying the KMD currency as an unregistered security and a fraudulent fund raise? Or is the creation and development of KMD so decentralized that there is no company or organization that can be held accountable and penalized?

Author: Arno#3334
Content: (like with Bitcoin?)

Author: Arno#3334
Content: I'm just wondering how safe we can feel in that regard.

Author: CHMEX#0686
Content: I would compare it with bitcoin as you described it

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: we delivered on all ICO promises, have a howey letter, no corporation to date, pretty decentralized

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: also, all the aspects that usually make something a security is in other coins, like DEX, SUPERNET

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: KMD is strictly a currency

Author: Arno#3334
Content: ok, thanks!

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if you notice the SEC actions, they are going after the very biggest and the most extreme of ICO that was basically a fraud. I saw some list of top crypto projects by american govt, KMD was in the top 40

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the ICO that spend on marketing without a product, those are the ones that need to worry

Author: Arno#3334
Content: Generally it's one thing what oneself believes is so, or is true, and another thing what the SEC simply claims. Veritaseum comes to mind, which was really not a big ICO first of all, and they released a long public statement why the SEC's allegations were actually wrong, but still the SEC could claim whatever they wanted and pretend that's true.

Author: Arno#3334
Content: And successfully charged them.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: what tech did veritaseum release?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: last i saw it was just a QT wallet

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: centralized service

Author: Arno#3334
Content: peer to peer capital markets

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but did it actually work?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i didnt see any decentralized tech come out of that project

Author: Arno#3334
Content: Yes, they are quite far already with their development, working beta.

Author: Arno#3334
Content: https://dapp.veritaseum.com/

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: how is a website decentralized?

Author: Arno#3334
Content: Haha, good question. No, they are a company of course, having sold the ERC20 VERI token as "pre-paid fees for their peer-to-peer services".

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you can say "peer to peer capital markets", but what does that mean in terms of tech

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so they have a centralized service and the token sale was prepaid fees, for this centralized service

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and they dont have any tech at the protocol level, it is just an ERC20 token

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and you are thinking this is in anyway comparable to komodo?

Author: Arno#3334
Content: proprietary tech, in that sense, yes. A business model. No whitepaper. Reggie Middleton always compared this to: has Microsoft released a whitepaper? No, they have a business model, and created a lot of licenses for the services (here: the VERI token), that they can sell as they like (here: ICO)

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: didnt they raise $20 mil or so?

Author: Arno#3334
Content: I think so.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so a closed source, centrally controlled service, sold as prepaid tokens. you do realize this is about as far away from komodo as you can get

Author: Arno#3334
Content: yes.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: komodo isnt a business

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: there is no business model for KMD

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it is a coin and the ICO was done to raise BTC needed for dPoW txfees, and we finished that and started notarized within months after the ICO was finished

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: my understanding is that as soon as we completed our ICO promises, and KMD started trading freely on the markets, it is not any security

Author: Arno#3334
Content: I see.

Content: I only raised it because these days it feels they're trying to come after any project they might want, potentially anything that could be a (in their view threatening) alternative to the established fiat monetary system, whether the claim is valid or not. It's simply good to be prepared for anything.

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: Doubt it.

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: Gabelli v. Securities and Exchange Commission, No. 11-1274, the United States Supreme Court clarified that the 5-year statute of limitations applicable to SEC enforcement actions that seek financial penalties begins to accrue when the alleged violation occurs, not when the SEC discovers the violation.  This decision may have implications not only for SEC enforcement actions, but for other government proceedings seeking a civil fine, penalty, or forfeiture.

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: https://www.paulweiss.com/practices/litigation/securities-litigation/publications/us-supreme-court-clarifies-scope-of-5-year-statute-of-limitations-in-sec-enforcement-proceedings?id=12684

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: Supernet August 2014 = past statute of limitations.

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: Also from the ‚Äúspirit of the law‚Äù sense there are thousands of projects that are much easier targets and near infinitely more culpable than KMD or james assets
